page.title: 07BUILDINGS IN CROOK,CUMBRIA
page.content: BUILDINGS ARE A BLEND OF THE OLD AND NEW,PREDOMINANTLY THE GREY OF STONE AND SLATE WITH HERE AND THERE A RENDERING OF WHITE.ALL THE FARMS ARE VERY OLD,SOME BUILT DURING THE 14TH OR 15TH CENTURY.ONE STILL RETAINS ROUND CHIMNEYS,A TYPICAL FEATURE OF LAKELAND ARCHITECTURE,BUILT TO WITHSTAND THE FIERCE WINDS PREVALENT DURING WINTER.REMAINS OF THE ORIGINAL PELE TOWER STAND,SHOWING THE BARREL-VAULTED CELLAR,AND WALLS BETWEEN 3 AND 5 FEET THICK.ANOTHER FARM,BUILT IN THE 16TH CENTURY,HAS WALLS UP TO 3 FEET THICK, AND A VERY EARLY TYPE OF WINDOW IN ONE OF THE END WALLS. MODERN FARM BUILDINGS ARE TO BE SEEN NEARBY OR EVEN ATTACHED TO THE OLD ONES.CONCRETE SHEDS FOR HOUSING FARM MACHINERY CONTRAST SHARPLY WITH THE ORIGINAL STONE BUILT BARNS WITH ROOFS OF LAKELAND SLATE.
